instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
Board was water damaged. Cleaned with UC. Damaged areas showed in pictures. After cleaning, looks pretty good, including under SMC. 

Rails present & stable: 
PPBUS
PP3V42
PPVRTC
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

Not present:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0.235V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
Did you reball SMC?
Does it start in SMC bypass mode?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Any pulse (at least) at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
I haven't done anything to SMC yet.
It doesn't start in SMC bypass mode.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0.02V (no pulse)
DCPS shows 30mA steady draw. It hangs somewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message: You must flux and heat the board at least before UC....likely crap under the SMC still also could have an issue with <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>, clock chip, <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> etc. First, reflow the SMC and see if any change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message: Okay. Before I do that, I went around a bit and found <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> having 3.5Ohms. So hopefully not PCH or SMC pulling it down... Should I first try to remove other components on that rails and check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
There are few chips you can remove before; <CHIP>U2030</CHIP>/3510/4810,
Look if <RESISTOR>R1461</RESISTOR> has no corrosion around.
If still low value, put good flux and heat SMC first; next one, PCH.

I stillrecommend to reball SMC.
Don't forget to check if short is gone when SMC is removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
Okay, I lifted mentioned chips (except SMC and PCH, of course) and nothing changed. Then I heated SMC with flux and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is back to 100kOhms.

I wanted to check for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> value and checked wrong resistor (<RESISTOR>R1995</RESISTOR>) instead of <RESISTOR>R1461</RESISTOR>. Basically, <RESISTOR>R1995</RESISTOR> shows <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> being 0 Ohms.

Power hasn't been pushed through motherboard. I'd rather like to probe around for shorted things instead of pushing power. 

Am I thinking logically here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
Never power up the board if you detect a short.
In this case is safe to inject voltage on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> line.
Start with 1V, and go high maintaining ampers bellow PSU current limit.
However, stop before reaching 4V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> shorted
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> shorted. 

Injected 1V into <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and CPU gets hot around pin 1147.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage around SMC
threads.message: If you get two (or more) different power rails shorted to ground, and both (all) go to a common chip, guess which is the culprit...
